entry.title: Combined summary - Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: In a discussion about front-running and peer-to-peer marketplaces, Antoine Riard explains that front-running resistance is a concern in the CivKit architecture. The design assumption is that if a bulletin board operator like Bob can collect outsized profits, other participants like Terry the Taker will eventually move to other markets. This model ends up resembling a brokerage rather than an exchange market structure. Antoine suggests that Terry should open his own brokerage and compete on quoting prices with Bob. By comparing metrics like execution quality, Bob and Terry can draw more market activity by providing better prices. Antoine also notes that front-running is a good problem to have as it indicates active participants and liquidity in the market.Antoine discusses two security paradigms to mitigate front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace. The first paradigm involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities and monitoring latency anomalies. If repeated anomalies occur, makers can disqualify the misbehaving board from future announcements. However, this approach is not perfect and can be exploited by boards if the monitoring frequency is known. The second paradigm involves running bulletin boards as a federation using Honey Badger BFT or similar techniques. Offers become consensus items that must be announced to all federation members, ensuring fairness and preventing front-running.Antoine mentions that the CivKit framework offers flexibility for peer-to-peer marketplaces, allowing parameters like propagation latency monitoring and federation set and rules to be adjusted based on the types of trades and market participants' tolerance. The configuration of these parameters will depend on real-world deployments. Antoine concludes by stating that mass front-running on the board would be a "champagne" issue to have, indicating a thriving market with active participants and liquidity.In an email thread, a group of researchers discusses a concept called front-running in peer-to-peer marketplaces, where traders enter into trades with advance knowledge of block transactions that will influence the price of underlying securities. The concern is that bulletin board operators may engage in front-running, but there are security paradigms to mitigate this risk. One paradigm involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards and monitoring latency for anomalies. Another paradigm suggests running the bulletin boards as a federation under Honey Badger BFT, where incoming board offers become consensus items that must be announced to all federation members before adoption.The Civkit proposes a flexible framework for peer-to-peer marketplaces, allowing for adaptation to different types of trades and market participants' tolerance for front-running resistance. The design combines the Nostr architecture of simple relays announcing trade orders with Lightning onion routing infrastructure. The market boards are Nostr relays with a Lightning gateway, operating autonomously and in competition. Trades are escrowed under Bitcoin Script contracts, relying on moderations and know your peer oracles for adjudication. The goal is to support on-ramp/off-ramp trading and eventually extend to other types of trading, including goods, services, and bitcoin financial derivatives.Antoine Riard, Nicholas Gregory, and Ray Youssef have been working on a peer-to-peer market system that enables censorship-resistant and permissionless global trading. The design combines the Nostr architecture with Lightning onion routing infrastructure to provide confidentiality to market participants. The market boards can be run as a federation, although there is no decentralized orderbook logged into the blockchain. Trades are escrowed under Bitcoin Script contracts, relying on moderations and know your peer oracles for adjudication.One feedback received on the paper publication highlights the importance of underscoring front-running resistance as a fundamental property for a peer-to-peer marketplace. The level of front-running resistance aimed by market participants will depend on the types of trades considered. The paper proposes two security paradigms to mitigate front-running risks: duplicating offer announcements to concurrent boards and monitoring latency, and running bulletin boards as a federation under Honey Badger BFT.The researchers propose the introduction of a Web-of-Stakes for scoring trades, counterparties, and service operators. This reputation paradigm could be combined with decentralized identifiers and state-of-the-art Web-of-Trust techniques. They also suggest a consistent incentive framework for service operators through privacy-preserving credentials backed by Bitcoin payments, following the principles of IETF's Privacy Pass.The whitepaper delves deep into the architecture of the system, and the researchers plan to release code and modules gradually, building on the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries. They aim to collaborate with the community to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients in the long term. Feedback on their work is highly encouraged.
